availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

person.persName: Charles W. Blandford (Nelson County, KY, carpenter)

body.p: Nelson County, Kentucky, carpenter. Kentucky native. Son of J. H. Blandford and L. A. Blandford. Married to Martha Whalen Blandford in Nelson County on November 18, 1856. Father of Eugene Blandford, John Blandford, Annie G. Blandford, and Charles Blandford. Carpenter with father, J. H. Blandford, in Nelson County in 1850. Household owned two enslaved persons in Nelson County in 1850. House carpenter in Nelson County in 1860. Employed John Lilly and William Brewer as carpenter's apprentices in Nelson County in 1860. Owned one enslaved person in Nelson County in 1860. Carpenter in Nelson County in 1863.

ab.bibl:
Seventh Manuscript Census of the United States (1850), Population Schedules, Kentucky, Nelson County, District 1, p. 282B.
Seventh Manuscript Census of the United States (1850), Slave Schedules, Kentucky, Nelson County, District 1, p. 155.
Eighth Manuscript Census of the United States (1860), Population Schedules, Kentucky, Nelson County, District 2, Bardstown, p. 3.
Eighth Manuscript Census of the United States (1860), Slave Schedules, Kentucky, Nelson County, District 2, p. 127A.
Ninth Manuscript Census of the United States (1870), Population Schedules, Kentucky, Nelson County, Bardstown, p. 62A.
Kentucky, County Marriage Records, 1783-1965, Kentucky, Nelson County, Film # 000481488, December 17, 1856 (accessed via ancestry.com).
Consolidated Lists of Civil War Draft Registration Records (Provost Marshal General's Bureau; Consolidated Enrollment Lists, 1863-1865), NARA RG 110, Kentucky, 4th Congressional District, Vol. 2, August 1863, p. 41, p. 58 of microfilm, (Accessed via ancestry.com on April 21, 2020).
